story.text: LIMA Jan 2 Peru's No. 4 copper mine, Cerro Verde (CVE.LM), has started shipping ore from a new concentrator facility built as part of an expansion project, the U.S.-based firm that controls the mine said on Tuesday. Phelps Dodge Corp. PD.N, which holds a majority stake in Cerro Verde, said 9,500 tonnes of copper concentrate shipped to Sumitomo Metal Mining Co Ltd (5713.T) for processing, had been produced in pre-operational trials. Sumitomo is a major shareholder in Cerro Verde. "The new concentrator associated with the expansion is operating but not yet at full capacity," it said in a statement, adding that it expected to achieve full production in the first half of this year. Cerro Verde, based in southern Peru, is undergoing an $850 million expansion plan to triple its production to about 300,000 tonnes a year and extend the mine's life by about 26 years. The expansion started in 2005. Some one billion tonnes of sulphide ore reserves averaging 0.51 percent copper will be processed through the new concentrator, the statement said. The expansion will also allow the plant to produce more than 2,000 tonnes of molybdenum annually, it added. Peru is the world's third largest copper producer.
story.title: peru ' s cerro verde expanded mine starts shipping
